titleproper.value: Guide to the Paul Cronin Anti-War Protest Photographs <num>TAM 637</num>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

p.value: Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated in 2013 by Paul Cronin. The accession number associated with this gift is 2013.042.

Paul Cronin (1972, London) is co-founder of Sticking Place Films, a production and distribution company in London. His films include <emph render="italic">Look out Haskell, It's real!</emph>, <emph render="italic">The Making of Medium Cool</emph> (2001), <emph render="italic">Film as a Subversive Art: Amos Vogel and Cinema 16</emph> (2003), and <emph render="italic">In the Beginning was the Image: Conversations with Peter Whitehead</emph> (2006). He is also the editor of several books on the film industry, including <emph render="italic">Herzog on Herzog</emph> and <emph render="italic">Alexander Mackendrick's On Film-Making: An Introduction to the Craft of the Director</emph>. Cronin is currently he working on <emph render="italic">A Time to Stir</emph>, an historical documentary about the student protests at Columbia University in 1968, set to be released in 2018.

This collection contains roughly 400 black and white photogrphs pertaining to student anti-war protests in the 1960s and early 1970s. The majority of these photographs relate to student anti-war protest in the United States, but several also relate to foreign protests and other general anti-war protests in the United States, most notably the Poor People's Campaign of 1968. Other notable topics covered in this collection include protests at San Francisco State University Protests and University of California Berkely, and the "Stop the Draft" demonstration led by pacifics Linda Morse.
